com.pb.sawdust.util

Enum JavaType

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<JavaType>
      • com.pb.sawdust.util.JavaType
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<JavaType>

    public enum JavaType
extends java.lang.Enum<JavaType>
    The JavaType enum provides a structure for differentiating between Java primitives and objects. Essentially, there is one enum constant for each primitive type, as well as one representing a Java object. This enum will generally be used when dealing with generics, which don't handle primitives, and especially with generics' iteractions with arrays.

    • Enum Constant Summary

      INT
      Constant representing the int primitive type.
      LONG
      Constant representing the long primitive type.
      OBJECT
      Constant representing the Object type (i.e. anything non-primitive).
      SHORT
      Constant representing the short primitive type.

      • values

        public static JavaType[] values()
        Returns an array containing the constants of this enum type, in the order they are declared. This method may be used to iterate over the constants as follows: 
        for (JavaType c : JavaType.values())
    System.out.println(c);
        Returns:
        an array containing the constants of this enum type, in the order they are declared

      • valueOf

        public static JavaType valueOf(java.lang.String name)

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the enum constant with the specified name

      • isPrimitive

        public boolean isPrimitive()
        Indicates whether this enum constant represents a primitive type or not.
        Returns:
        true if this enum constant represents a primitive type, false otherwise.

      • getClassEquivalent

        public java.lang.Class getClassEquivalent()
        Get the class which corresponds to the type this enum constant represents. For OBJECT, this will return Object.class; for all other constants, this method will return their primitive class instance.
        Returns:
        the class corresponding to the type this enum constant represents.

      • getObjectEquivalent

        public java.lang.Class getObjectEquivalent()
        Get the class which which corresponds to the object equivalent of the type this enum constant represents. For example, BYTE.getObjectEquivalent() returns the Byte.class class. For the OBJECT type, the object equivalent returned is Object.class.
        Returns:
        the class corresponding to this enum type's object equivalent.

      • isNumeric

        public boolean isNumeric()
        Indicates whether this java type is numeric or not. The numeric types are BYTE, SHORT, INT, LONG, FLOAT, and DOUBLE.
        Returns:
        true if this type is a numeric type, false if not.

      • getPrimitiveSize

        public int getPrimitiveSize()
        Return the size in bytes of the primitive equivalent of this java type, as specified by the Java Language Specification. For the BOOLEAN type, this returns the same as the INT type; even though the boolean size is not strictly defined by the JLS, it generally maps to an int in a JVM.
        Returns:
        the size of this type's associated primitive.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if this java type is OBJECT, as it has no associated primitive.

      • getDefaultObject

        public java.lang.Object getDefaultObject()
        Get the default value of this java type, as an object. For type with primitive equivalents, this is the (boxed) object value of the default primitive value specified by the JLS. For the OBJECT type, this method returns null.
        Returns:
        the default value of this java type.

      • getJavaType

        public static JavaType getJavaType(java.lang.Class<?> type)
        Get the type associated with a given class. If the class is a primitive, the appropriate JavaType is returned, otherwise OBJECT is returned.
        Parameters:
        type - The class is question.
        Returns:
        the type corresponding to type.

      • getPrimitiveJavaType

        public static JavaType getPrimitiveJavaType(java.lang.Class<?> type)
        Get the primtive type associated with a given class. If the class is a primitive, the appropriate JavaType is returned; if the class is an object equivalent to a primitive class, the appropriate JavaType corresponding to that primitive class is returned; otherwise OBJECT is returned.
        Parameters:
        type - The class is question.
        Returns:
        the type corresponding to type.

      • getComponentType

        public static JavaType getComponentType(java.lang.Object array)
        Determine the component type of an input array. If the input is not a primitive array, then this method will return OBJECT, as Object[] is a supertype of all object arrays.
        Parameters:
        array - The input array.
        Returns:
        the component type array.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if array is not a java array.

      • getBaseComponentType

        public static JavaType getBaseComponentType(java.lang.Object array)
        Get the base component type of an array. The base component type of an array is the final type that the array holds: for one dimensional arrays, this is the same as its componenet type; for multidimensional arrays this is the type that the multidimensional array holds. For example, a byte[][] array will have a base type of BYTE, though calling getComponentType(Object) on it would return OBJECT since its component class is byte[]. If the array's base compnoent type not primitive, then OBJECT will be returned.
        Parameters:
        array - The input array.
        Returns:
        the base component type of array.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if array is not a java array.

      • getWideningType

        public static JavaType getWideningType(JavaType type1,
                       JavaType type2)
        Get the type which represents a "widening" conversion when casting between primitives. That is, for the two types being compared, get the type which the other would need to be cast to for a widening conversion. Widening means roughly what the Java Language Specification specifies in section 5.1. The only exceptions are that BOOLEAN is always widened to the other type (the JLS doesn't allow casting to/from booleans), and CHAR is always widened to a numeric type (casting between char and byte or short is ambiguous). As it does not apply here, passing OBJECT as either argument will cause an exception to be thrown.
        Parameters:
        type1 - The first type.
        type2 - The second type.
        Returns:
        the type (among type1 and type2) which represents the widening direction.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if either argument is OBJECT.
